did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: The collection contains clippings, flyers for events and facilities, guides and handbooks, memoranda and correspondence, newsletters, menus and prices, and recipes and other materials concerning Duke University's Dining Services. This collection was compiled from a variety of sources by the University Archives for use in reference and research.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: Copyright for Official University records is held by Duke University; all other copyright is retained by the authors of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Dining Services Reference Collection, Duke University Archives, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Dining Services Reference Collection was compiled by University Archives staff from a variety of sources.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions were merged into one collection, described in this finding aid.
Descriptive sources and standards used to create this inventory: DACS, EAD, NCEAD guidelines, and our local Style Guide.
This finding aid is NCEAD compliant.

chronitem.event: East Union opens – Board Cafeteria; "Dope Shop" snack bar opens in Crowell building
West Union opens – 2 a la carte cafeterias
Ted Minah becomes Food Services Director (1946-1974)
the independent union, the Duke Employee Benevolent society was organized (February 1965); they affiliated with the AFSCME (American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees)in Sept. 1965
Merger of Woman's College and Trinity College
Central Campus apartment completed – no dining facilities
Mandatory Board eliminated on East Campus; electronic debit account implemented
Bryan Center completed (1983 – first privatization initiative)
Duke Card/non-traditional dining options available; enhancement projects completed on Central Campus bringing Uncle Harry's and The Pub.
Dining Facilities retrenched to East Union – food court/cafeteria renovation; Gilbert-Addoms facility closed; "Dope Shop"closed
First franchise brand (Li'l Dino Subs) and first national brand (Burger King) installed
Levine Science Resource Center (LSRC) Dining Hall opens.
the Marketplace on East Campus opens
The Loop opens its doors; McDonald's opens in the Bryan Center
Duke selects ARAMARK corp. to manage food services at eight campus dining locations including the Great Hall and the Marketplace
The Refectory, a “green” environment-friendly eatery, opens in the Divinity School
the Compass Group replaces ARAMARK as the dining management company.

In July, the operation of West Campus' main dining area switched hands from Chartwells to Bon Appetit, a branch of the Compass Group; Faculty Commons changes its name to Upstairs@The Commons, and opens its doors to students.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The collection contains clippings, flyers for events and facilities, guides and handbooks, memoranda and correspondence, newsletters, menus and prices, and recipes and other materials concerning Duke University's Dining Services.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.
